canonical_explanation.text: Trigonometry is used to find heights and distances of objects that cannot be measured directly. The angle of elevation is the angle above the horizontal when looking up at an object, and the angle of depression is the angle below the horizontal when looking down. These problems involve right triangles formed using horizontal distances, vertical heights, and lines of sight.
rules: Angle of elevation is measured upward from the horizontal line of sight
Angle of depression is measured downward from the horizontal line of sight
Angle of elevation from A to B = Angle of depression from B to A (alternate interior angles)
Use tan when relating height and horizontal distance
Use sin when relating height and line of sight (hypotenuse)
Use cos when relating horizontal distance and line of sight
Standard angles used: 30, 45, 60 degrees with known trig values

questions.question_text: The angle of elevation of the top of a tower from a point on the ground is the angle between:

options.text: The line of sight to the top and the horizontal
The line of sight to the top and the vertical

questions.explanation_correct: The angle of elevation is formed between the horizontal line of sight and the line of sight directed upward to the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angle of elevation is measured from the horizontal to the upward line of sight.

questions.question_text: The angle of depression of a point on the ground from the top of a building is the angle between:

options.text: The horizontal and the line of sight looking downward
The vertical and the line of sight

questions.explanation_correct: The angle of depression is measured from the horizontal at the observer's level downward to the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angle of depression is from the horizontal downward to the line of sight.

questions.question_text: The angle of elevation of the top of a tower from a point on the ground is equal to the angle of depression of the point from the top of the tower.
questions.explanation_correct: These are alternate interior angles formed by the horizontal lines (at ground level and at tower top) with the line of sight as transversal. So they are equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By alternate interior angles, the angle of elevation equals the angle of depression.

questions.question_text: If the angle of elevation of the sun is 45 degrees, the shadow of a pole is:

options.text: Equal to the height of the pole
Twice the height of the pole
Half the height of the pole

questions.explanation_correct: tan 45 = height/shadow = 1. So shadow = height.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan 45 = 1 means height = shadow length.

questions.question_text: As we move closer to the base of a tower, the angle of elevation of the top:
questions.explanation_correct: Moving closer to the base while the height remains the same increases the ratio height/distance, increasing the angle of elevation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Closer distance with same height means steeper angle, i.e., larger angle of elevation.

questions.question_text: A tower is 20 m high. The angle of elevation of its top from a point on the ground is 30 degrees. The distance of the point from the foot of the tower is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan 30 = height/distance = 20/d. d = 20*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: The angle of elevation of the top of a pole 10 m high from a point 10 m away from its base is:
questions.explanation_correct: tan A = 10/10 = 1, so A = 45 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan A = height/distance = 10/10 = 1, giving angle = 45 degrees.

questions.question_text: A kite is flying at a height of 30 m. The string attached to the kite makes an angle of 30 degrees with the ground. The length of the string is:
questions.explanation_correct: sin 30 = 30/length. So length = 30/sin 30 = 30/(1/2) = 60 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: sin 30 = height/string length = 30/L. L = 60 m.

questions.question_text: The shadow of a tower is sqrt(3) times its height. The angle of elevation of the sun is:
questions.explanation_correct: tan A = height/shadow = h/(sqrt(3)*h) = 1/sqrt(3). So A = 30 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan A = h/(sqrt(3)h) = 1/sqrt(3) = tan 30. Angle = 30 degrees.

questions.question_text: A ladder 10 m long leans against a wall making an angle of 60 degrees with the ground. The height at which the ladder reaches the wall is:
questions.explanation_correct: sin 60 = height/10. Height = 10 x sin 60 = 10 x sqrt(3)/2 = 5*sqrt(3) m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: sin 60 = height/ladder length. Height = 10 x sqrt(3)/2 = 5*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: If a 15 m tall tree casts a shadow of 15 m, the angle of elevation of the sun is 45 degrees.
questions.explanation_correct: tan A = height/shadow = 15/15 = 1. A = 45 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan A = 15/15 = 1. This gives A = 45 degrees.

questions.question_text: From the top of a 7 m high building, the angle of depression of the foot of a tower is 60 degrees. The distance between the building and the tower is:
questions.explanation_correct: Angle of depression = 60 degrees. tan 60 = 7/d. d = 7/sqrt(3) = 7*sqrt(3)/3 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan 60 = height/distance = 7/d. d = 7/sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: A person standing 40 m away from a building observes the top at an angle of elevation of 60 degrees. The height of the building is:
questions.explanation_correct: tan 60 = h/40. h = 40 x tan 60 = 40*sqrt(3) m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan 60 = height/40. Height = 40*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: The angle of elevation of the top of a 50 m tower from a point 50 m from its base is ___ degrees.
questions.explanation_correct: tan A = 50/50 = 1. A = 45 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan A = height/distance = 50/50 = 1, so A = 45 degrees.

questions.question_text: From the top of a cliff 80 m high, the angle of depression of a boat in the sea is 30 degrees. The distance of the boat from the base of the cliff is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan 30 = 80/d gives d = 80/(1/sqrt(3)) = 80*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: The angles of depression of the top and bottom of an 8 m tall building from the top of a multi-storied building are 30 degrees and 45 degrees respectively. The height of the multi-storied building is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let height of multi-storied building = h, distance = d. From bottom: tan 45 = h/d, so d = h. From top of 8 m building: tan 30 = (h-8)/d = (h-8)/h. So h/sqrt(3) = h - 8. h = sqrt(3)(h-8). h = sqrt(3)h - 8sqrt(3). h(sqrt(3)-1) = 8sqrt(3). h = 8sqrt(3)/(sqrt(3)-1) = 8sqrt(3)(sqrt(3)+1)/2 = 4sqrt(3)(sqrt(3)+1) = 4(3+sqrt(3)) = 4(sqrt(3)+3).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Setting up two equations using tan 45 and tan 30, and solving gives h = 4(sqrt(3)+3) m.

questions.question_text: From a point on the ground, the angles of elevation of the top and bottom of a flagstaff on a building are 60 degrees and 45 degrees. If the building is 10 m high, the height of the flagstaff is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let d = distance from building. tan 45 = 10/d, so d = 10. tan 60 = (10+f)/10 where f is flagstaff height. sqrt(3) = (10+f)/10. 10+f = 10*sqrt(3). f = 10(sqrt(3)-1) m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distance d = 10 m (from tan 45 = 10/d). Then tan 60 = (10+f)/10 gives f = 10(sqrt(3)-1) m.

questions.question_text: A tower stands vertically on the ground. From a point on the ground 30 m away, the angle of elevation of the top is 30 degrees. The height of the tower is:
A man 1.5 m tall stands at a distance of 8.5 m from a lamp post. His shadow is 3 m long on the ground. The height of the lamp post is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let lamp height = H. By similar triangles: H/(8.5+3) = 1.5/3. H/11.5 = 0.5. H = 5.75 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Similar triangles: H/11.5 = 1.5/3 = 0.5. H = 5.75 m.

questions.question_text: The angle of elevation of the top of a tree from a point at a distance of 20 m from its base is 60 degrees. The height of the tree is:
questions.explanation_correct: tan 60 = h/20. h = 20*sqrt(3) m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan 60 = height/20. Height = 20*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: A bridge across a river makes an angle of 45 degrees with the river bank. If the length of the bridge across the river is 150 m, the width of the river is:
questions.explanation_correct: sin 45 = width/150. Width = 150 x sin 45 = 150/sqrt(2) = 75*sqrt(2) m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: sin 45 = width/bridge. Width = 150 x (1/sqrt(2)) = 75*sqrt(2) m.

questions.question_text: Two poles of equal height stand on either side of a road 80 m wide. From a point between them on the road, the angles of elevation of the tops are 60 and 30 degrees. The height of each pole is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let height = h, point is at distance d from one pole. tan 60 = h/d and tan 30 = h/(80-d). From first: d = h/sqrt(3). From second: 80-d = h*sqrt(3). So 80 = h/sqrt(3) + h*sqrt(3) = h(1/sqrt(3) + sqrt(3)) = h(4/sqrt(3)). h = 80*sqrt(3)/4 = 20*sqrt(3) m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Setting up equations from both angles and solving: h = 20*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: From the top of a 60 m high lighthouse, the angle of depression of a ship is 30 degrees. The distance of the ship from the base of the lighthouse is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan 30 = 60/d gives d = 60*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: If the height of an object equals the length of its shadow, the angle of elevation of the sun is ___ degrees.
questions.explanation_correct: tan A = height/shadow = 1. A = 45 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan A = h/h = 1, so A = 45 degrees.

questions.question_text: A vertical pole 6 m high casts a shadow 2*sqrt(3) m long on the ground. The angle of elevation of the sun is:
questions.explanation_correct: tan A = 6/(2*sqrt(3)) = 3/sqrt(3) = sqrt(3). A = 60 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan A = 6/(2*sqrt(3)) = sqrt(3) = tan 60. Angle = 60 degrees.

questions.question_text: From the top of a 12 m high building, the angle of elevation of the top of a tower is 60 degrees and the angle of depression of its foot is 30 degrees. The height of the tower is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let distance = d. tan 30 = 12/d, so d = 12*sqrt(3). Let tower height above building = x. tan 60 = x/d = x/(12*sqrt(3)). x = 12*sqrt(3)*sqrt(3) = 36. Total tower height = 36 + 12 = 48 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distance d = 12*sqrt(3) m. Height above building = 12*sqrt(3)*tan 60 = 36 m. Total = 48 m.

questions.question_text: An aeroplane is flying at a height of 300 m. The angle of depression of a point on the ground is 60 degrees. The distance of the point from the point directly below the aeroplane is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan 60 = 300/d gives d = 300/sqrt(3) = 100*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: A tree breaks due to storm and the broken part bends so that the top touches the ground at an angle of 30 degrees at a distance of 12 m from the root. The height of the tree is:
questions.explanation_correct: Standing part h = 12 x tan 30 = 12/sqrt(3) = 4*sqrt(3) m. Broken part (hypotenuse) l = 12/cos 30 = 12/(sqrt(3)/2) = 24/sqrt(3) = 8*sqrt(3) m. Total height = 4*sqrt(3) + 8*sqrt(3) = 12*sqrt(3) m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Standing part = 12 tan 30 = 4*sqrt(3). Broken part = 12/cos 30 = 8*sqrt(3). Total = 12*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: If a man observes the top of a tower at an angle of elevation of 30 degrees and then walks 20 m towards the tower and finds the angle of elevation to be 60 degrees, the height of the tower is 10*sqrt(3) m.
questions.explanation_correct: Let height = h, initial distance = d. tan 30 = h/d gives d = h*sqrt(3). tan 60 = h/(d-20) gives d - 20 = h/sqrt(3). So h*sqrt(3) - 20 = h/sqrt(3). h*sqrt(3) - h/sqrt(3) = 20. h(3-1)/sqrt(3) = 20. 2h/sqrt(3) = 20. h = 10*sqrt(3).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Setting up two equations with tan 30 and tan 60 and solving gives h = 10*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: From the top of a 15 m high building, the angle of elevation of the top of a tower is 30 degrees. From the foot of the building, the angle of elevation of the top of the tower is 60 degrees. The height of the tower is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let tower height = H, distance = d. From foot: tan 60 = H/d, so d = H/sqrt(3). From building top: tan 30 = (H-15)/d. 1/sqrt(3) = (H-15)/(H/sqrt(3)) = sqrt(3)(H-15)/H. H/(sqrt(3)*sqrt(3)) = H - 15. H/3 = H - 15. 15 = H - H/3 = 2H/3. H = 22.5 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using two equations: d = H/sqrt(3) and tan 30 = (H-15)/d, solving gives H = 22.5 m.

questions.question_text: A pole casts a shadow of length equal to sqrt(3) times its height. The angle of elevation of the sun is:
questions.explanation_correct: tan A = h/(sqrt(3)*h) = 1/sqrt(3). A = 30 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan A = height/shadow = 1/sqrt(3). Angle = 30 degrees.

questions.question_text: A 1.5 m tall boy is standing at some distance from a 30 m tall building. The angle of elevation from his eyes to the top of the building increases from 30 to 60 degrees as he walks towards the building. The distance he walked is:
questions.explanation_correct: Height above eyes = 30 - 1.5 = 28.5 m. Initial: tan 30 = 28.5/d1, d1 = 28.5*sqrt(3). Final: tan 60 = 28.5/d2, d2 = 28.5/sqrt(3) = 9.5*sqrt(3). Distance walked = d1 - d2 = 28.5*sqrt(3) - 9.5*sqrt(3) = 19*sqrt(3) m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Effective height = 28.5 m. Distance walked = 28.5*sqrt(3) - 28.5/sqrt(3) = 19*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: The angle of elevation of the top of a building from the foot of the tower is 30 degrees and the angle of elevation of the top of the tower from the foot of the building is 60 degrees. If the tower is 50 m high, the height of the building is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let building height = h, distance = d. tan 60 = 50/d, so d = 50/sqrt(3). tan 30 = h/d. h = d x tan 30 = (50/sqrt(3)) x (1/sqrt(3)) = 50/3 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: d = 50/sqrt(3). h = d x tan 30 = 50/(sqrt(3)*sqrt(3)) = 50/3 m.

questions.question_text: From the top of a 25 m high tower, the angle of depression of a car on the road is 30 degrees. The car is ___ m from the base of the tower. (Express in terms of sqrt(3))
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan 30 = 25/d gives d = 25*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: A statue 1.6 m tall stands on the top of a pedestal. From a point on the ground, the angle of elevation of the top of the statue is 60 degrees and of the top of the pedestal is 45 degrees. The height of the pedestal is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let pedestal height = p, distance = d. tan 45 = p/d, so d = p. tan 60 = (p+1.6)/d = (p+1.6)/p. sqrt(3) = 1 + 1.6/p. 1.6/p = sqrt(3) - 1. p = 1.6/(sqrt(3)-1) = 1.6(sqrt(3)+1)/2 = 0.8(sqrt(3)+1).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using tan 45 and tan 60 equations: p = 1.6/(sqrt(3)-1) = 0.8(sqrt(3)+1) m.

questions.question_text: The angle of depression and the angle of elevation are always measured from the vertical line.
questions.explanation_correct: Both angles of elevation and depression are measured from the horizontal line, not the vertical.
questions.explanation_incorrect: These angles are measured from the horizontal line of sight.

questions.question_text: A vertical tower stands on a horizontal plane. From a point 25 m away from the base, the angle of elevation of the top is 60 degrees. The height of the tower is:
questions.explanation_correct: tan 60 = h/25. h = 25*sqrt(3) m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: h = 25 x tan 60 = 25*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: Two ships are on either side of a lighthouse. The angles of depression from the top of the 100 m lighthouse are 30 and 45 degrees. The distance between the two ships is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: d1 = 100*sqrt(3) and d2 = 100. Total distance = 100(sqrt(3)+1) m.

questions.question_text: An observer 1.5 m tall is 28.5 m away from a chimney. The angle of elevation of the top of the chimney from her eyes is 45 degrees. The height of the chimney is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Height above eyes = 28.5 x tan 45 = 28.5 m. Total height = 28.5 + 1.5 = 30 m.

questions.question_text: From the top of a 40 m tower, the angle of depression of a car is 45 degrees. The distance of the car from the base of the tower is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan 45 = 40/d gives d = 40 m since tan 45 = 1.

questions.question_text: From a point on a bridge across a river, the angles of depression of the banks on opposite sides are 30 and 45 degrees. If the bridge is at a height of 3 m from the banks, the width of the river is:
questions.explanation_correct: d1 = 3/tan 30 = 3*sqrt(3) m. d2 = 3/tan 45 = 3 m. Width = 3*sqrt(3) + 3 = 3(sqrt(3) + 1) m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Width = 3*sqrt(3) + 3 = 3(sqrt(3) + 1) m.

questions.question_text: A tower and a building stand opposite each other. The angle of elevation of the top of the tower from the top of a 20 m building is 30 degrees, and from the bottom is 45 degrees. The height of the tower is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let tower height = H, distance = d. tan 45 = H/d, so d = H. tan 30 = (H-20)/H. 1/sqrt(3) = (H-20)/H. H = sqrt(3)(H-20). H = sqrt(3)H - 20sqrt(3). H(sqrt(3)-1) = 20sqrt(3). H = 20sqrt(3)/(sqrt(3)-1) = 20sqrt(3)(sqrt(3)+1)/2 = 10sqrt(3)(sqrt(3)+1) = 10(3+sqrt(3)) m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: From tan 45 and tan 30: H = 20sqrt(3)/(sqrt(3)-1) = 10(3+sqrt(3)) m.

questions.question_text: A ladder leaning against a wall makes an angle of 60 degrees with the horizontal. If the foot of the ladder is 2.5 m from the wall, the length of the ladder is ___ m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: cos 60 = distance/ladder = 2.5/L. L = 2.5 x 2 = 5 m.

questions.question_text: As observed from the top of a 75 m high lighthouse, the angles of depression of two ships are 30 and 45 degrees. If one ship is exactly behind the other on the same side, the distance between the ships is:
questions.explanation_correct: Ship at 45 degrees: d1 = 75/tan 45 = 75 m. Ship at 30 degrees: d2 = 75/tan 30 = 75*sqrt(3) m. Distance between ships = d2 - d1 = 75*sqrt(3) - 75 = 75(sqrt(3) - 1) m.

questions.question_text: A straight highway leads to the foot of a tower. A man standing on the top of the tower observes a car at an angle of depression 30 degrees. The car is approaching the tower. After 6 seconds, the angle becomes 60 degrees. The time taken by the car to reach the foot of the tower from this point is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let h = height, speed = v. At 30 degrees: d1 = h*sqrt(3). At 60 degrees: d2 = h/sqrt(3). Distance covered in 6s = d1 - d2 = h*sqrt(3) - h/sqrt(3) = 2h/sqrt(3). Speed = 2h/(6*sqrt(3)). Time to cover d2 = (h/sqrt(3)) / (2h/(6*sqrt(3))) = (h/sqrt(3)) x (6*sqrt(3)/(2h)) = 6/2 = 3 seconds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the ratio of distances at 30 and 60 degrees, the remaining time = 3 seconds.

questions.question_text: If the angle of elevation of the sun changes from 45 to 30 degrees, the shadow of a tower:
questions.explanation_correct: Lower angle of elevation means the sun is lower in the sky, casting a longer shadow. tan decreases from tan 45 = 1 to tan 30 = 1/sqrt(3), so shadow = h/tan increases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Smaller elevation angle means longer shadow.

questions.question_text: A TV tower stands vertically on the bank of a canal. From a point on the other bank directly opposite, the angle of elevation of the top is 60 degrees. From a point 20 m further away from this point, the angle of elevation is 30 degrees. The height of the tower is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let height = h, canal width = d. tan 60 = h/d, d = h/sqrt(3). tan 30 = h/(d+20). 1/sqrt(3) = h/(h/sqrt(3)+20). h/sqrt(3) + 20 = h*sqrt(3). 20 = h*sqrt(3) - h/sqrt(3) = h(3-1)/sqrt(3) = 2h/sqrt(3). h = 10*sqrt(3).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Setting up equations with tan 60 and tan 30: h = 10*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: If the angle of depression of a point A from point B is 40 degrees, then the angle of elevation of B from A is also 40 degrees.
questions.explanation_correct: Angle of depression from B to A = angle of elevation from A to B (alternate interior angles with horizontal lines).
questions.explanation_incorrect: These are alternate interior angles and hence equal.

questions.question_text: A man standing on the deck of a ship 10 m above sea level observes the angle of elevation of the top of a hill as 60 degrees and the angle of depression of the base as 30 degrees. The distance of the hill from the ship is:
questions.explanation_correct: tan 30 = 10/d. d = 10*sqrt(3) m. This is the horizontal distance from the ship to the hill.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan 30 = 10/d gives d = 10/tan 30 = 10*sqrt(3) m.

questions.question_text: A man on the top of a vertical tower observes a car moving at a uniform speed coming directly towards the tower. If it takes 12 minutes for the angle of depression to change from 30 to 45 degrees, the time taken after that to reach the tower is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let height = h. d1 = h*sqrt(3) (at 30 degrees), d2 = h (at 45 degrees). Distance in 12 min = h*sqrt(3) - h = h(sqrt(3)-1). Speed = h(sqrt(3)-1)/12. Time for remaining d2 = h = h / [h(sqrt(3)-1)/12] = 12/(sqrt(3)-1) = 12(sqrt(3)+1)/2 = 6(sqrt(3)+1) minutes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remaining distance = h, speed = h(sqrt(3)-1)/12. Time = 12/(sqrt(3)-1) = 6(sqrt(3)+1) minutes.
